thread.title_full: Ex-Rabobank Trader Complained to Regulators About Libor in 2006 - Bloomberg Business

author: Patricia Hurtado
title: Ex-Rabobank Trader Complained to Regulators About Libor in 2006
text:
A former Rabobank Groep trader complained to no avail to British regulators in 2006 that banks were rigging interest rates, according to e-mails shown a New York jury at the first U.S. prosecution of alleged manipulation of the London interbank offered rate.
Officials at the British Bankers’ Association didn’t understand his concerns, Paul Robson, the former trader, wrote to a Rabobank colleague in Tokyo. The rigging was making Libor “a joke again,” he said.
The e-mails were shown Wednesday to a jury in the trial of Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, former Rabobank traders who are accused of taking part in a four-year scheme to manipulate Libor, which is the benchmark tied to more than $350 trillion of loans and securities.
They were presented by a defense attorney apparently to support an argument that the traders didn’t engage in a scheme to manipulate the benchmark but were doing their best in setting Libor. They’ve also argued that Libor became meaningless during the 2008 financial crisis.
Robson and Takayuki Yagama, his Tokyo colleague, pleaded guilty to taking part in the same scheme, and agreed to cooperate with the U.S. government and testify at the trial.
The case is U.S. v. Allen, 14-cr-272, U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York (Manhattan).
